During the high-temperature hydrothermal aging process, the tolerance of the zeolite structure and the stability of the active Cu2+ ions directly determined the denitration (deNO x ) performance of the copper-based zeolite catalysts in automobile exhaust treatment. Herein, we displayed the hydrothermal aging stability of La-free and La-doped Cu/SAPO-34 catalysts at variant temperatures (650, 750 and 850 °C). A series of characterization results signified that the addition of La into SAPO-34 framework by ion exchange method had obvious contribution to hold back the collapse of SAPO-34 structure and transformation of isolated Cu2+ ions. Different from Cu/SAPO-34 catalyst, Cu/La-SAPO-34 catalyst was more prone to maintain its superior catalytic activity after hydrothermal aging at 750 °C, which possessed great application potential. In addition, NH3-TPD and DRIFT spectra shed light on the variation of surface acidity over two kinds of catalysts inducing by hydrothermal treatment. It could be discovered that doping of La provided moderate surface acidity and excellent hydrothermal stability for Cu/SAPO-34 even up to 750 °C, which was in favor of the NH3-SCR reaction. Graphical abstract The active Cu2+ ions in Cu/SAPO-34 are prone to migrate in the process of high temperature hydrothermal aging and thus became CuO clusters (Cu/S-750). The formed CuO species not only give rise to the loss of active SCR sites, but also cause the collapse of zeolite structure, eventually leading to the loss of acid sites on the catalyst surface. Fortunately, the doping of La (Cu/La-S-750) could effectively restrained the occurrence of these phenomena and maintain outstanding catalytic performance. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Zeolite structure Denitration performance Hydrothermal aging stability Cu2+ ions Surface acidity 1 Introduction The half-century development history of zeolite catalysts has witnessed the multi-functionality of zeolites on the catalytic performance. Owing to their unique shape-selectivity, diversified pore architectures and strong acidity, zeolites, such as, ZSM-5, SAPO-34, SSZ-13, Beta, eta, have been extensively investigated for decades for NH3-SCR reaction to alleviate the nitrogen oxides (NO x ) emissions from diesel vehicles [1–5]. Compared with ZSM-5, the microporous crystalline materials SAPO-34 and SSZ-13 with CHA structure have superior low-temperature SCR activity, wide temperature operating window, and excellent hydrothermal stability [2,6,7]. Among these two zeolites with the similar CHA structure, SAPO-34 is widely used because of its relatively low price [8]. In addition, copper-based zeolite catalysts have the highest potential for deNO x reaction due to their superior deNO x activity compared to iron-based zeolite catalysts, and higher N2 selectivity than manganese-based zeolite catalysts [8–10]. Unfortunately, copper-based zeolite catalysts are susceptible to hydrothermal aging conditions, and hydrothermal stability is a pivotal factor for zeolite lifetime to evaluate their practical application value [11]. The regeneration of the particulate trap (DPF) in the exhaust treatment of diesel vehicles will instantaneously raise the temperature to more than 650 °C, which can lead to rapid deactivation of catalyst [11,12]. Therefore, the requirements of hydrothermal stability for diesel vehicle deNO x catalyst are relatively stringent. In general, there are two primary reasons of zeolite deactivation in hot steam involved reaction. On the one hand, the destruction of zeolite structure is an essential reason [13,14]. It has been discovered that Brønsted acid sites of a zeolite are generally relate to the Al sites [15]. Gao et al. [16] reported that the residual isolated Al could afford ample Brønsted acid sites in Al-rich zeolites, facilitating the adsorption of reactive NH3 molecules determined the NH3-SCR activity of zeolite catalysts. However, the dealumination reaction often occurs under hot water/steam condition because these Al sites are hydrothermally unstable, which lead to the degrading adsorption or catalytic performances of zeolite [17]. Meanwhile, the loss of pore volume/surface area resulted from the collapse of zeolite framework is also contributed to the deactivation of zeolite catalysts [18]. On the other hand, the transformation of copper species from SCR active to fallow forms is a nonnegligible cause for zeolite deactivation [19–21]. The isolate Cu2+ ion species, usually acted as active deNO x sites, are prone to aggregate to form CuO x clusters under the hash hydrothermal aging conditions [22]. Gao and Szanyi [23] discover that the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst presents poor hydrothermal stability because of the presence of SCR inactive CuO clusters derived from the accumulation of isolate Cu2+ species, which not only cause the collapse of zeolite framework structure, but also give rise to the loss of active SCR sites. Hence, to overcome the detrimental effect of hydrothermal aging on deNO x catalysts, either stabilizing the zeolite framework or decreasing the mobility of isolate Cu2+ ions is commonly conducted in recent years [24–26]. For example, Li et al. [27] adjusted the Si content and Cu loading to achieve the stable framework and most amount of isolated Cu2+ of Cu-SAPO-18, contributing to the excellent SCR activity and hydrothermal stability. Beside, Zhao et al. [28] modified the Cu-SSZ-13 zeolites with phosphorus which could impede dealumination and structure collapse during hydrothermal aging, retaining the sufficient Cu2+ ions and outstanding NO reduction efficiency. In our previous study [29], we found that introduction of Ce or La could effectively mitigate the dealumination and inhibit the aggregation of Cu2+ ions over Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst during the hydrothermal aging at 700 °C. However, the specific effect of rare-earth ion introduction on the hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst at higher hydrothermal temperatures is not clear, and further work is required. Therefore, we studied the changes of catalytic activity and structural properties of the catalysts under different hydrothermal temperature to judge the tolerance limit of Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/La-SAPO-34 catalysts. In response to these phenomena, we systematically analyzed the deactivation mechanism of Cu-SAPO-34 to provide new insights for the preparation of the Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts with superior deNO x performance and hydrothermal stability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation La ion-exchanged SAPO-34 zeolite was synthesized through a ion-exchange method and SAPO-34 zeolite was purchased from Shanghai Shen Tan chemical new material Co. Ltd. Generally, La(NO3)3•6H2O was first dissolved in 100 mL deionized water, and the NH4-SAPO-34 zeolite was then added to La(NO3)3•6H2O solution and stirred continuously for 1 h. The pH of the mixture was set to 2.5 with diluted nitric acid, and the aimed mixture was continuously stirred at 80 °C of water bath for 12 h. Finally, the suspension was filtered and the resulting filter cake was washed several times with deionized water, followed by drying overnight at 80 °C. The synthetic protocol of Cu/SAPO-34 and La modified Cu/SAPO-34 samples were proposed by wet impregnation process. Typically, the SAPO-34 (La-SAPO-34) support was immersed in an aqueous solution of copper nitrate (Cu(NO3)2•3H2O, China National Medicines Company, ≥99.0%) and dried at 60 °C for 4 h while stirring. Subsequently, the resulting synthetic powder was dried at 80 °C for overnight and calcined at 550 °C for 3 h in stagnant air. Finally, the fresh Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/La-SAPO-34 catalysts with 5% Cu loading were denoted hereinafter as Cu/S-fresh and Cu/La-S-fresh for convenience, respectively. Cu/S-fresh (Cu/La-S-fresh) catalyst was then subjected to hydrothermal aging treatment in 10 vol% H2O/air at different temperatures (650, 750 and 850 °C) for 10 h. The aged samples were labeled as Cu/S-650 (Cu/La-S-650), Cu/S-750 (Cu/La-S-750), and Cu/S-850 (Cu/La-S-850), respectively. For comparison, Cu/S-fresh (Cu/La-S-fresh) was also separately performed at 750 °C for 32 h and 70 °C for 16 h, and the obtained samples were denoted as Cu/S-750-32 h (Cu/La-S-750-32 h) and Cu/S-LTH (Cu/La-S-LTH), respectively. 2.2 Catalysts characterization Textural properties of the prepared catalysts were measured on a TriStar II 3020 Micromeritics equipment using N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at −196 °C with the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The catalysts were previously degassed at 300 °C for 4 h under vacuum atmosphere before the nitrogen adsorption. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of samples were carried out on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with the use of Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.15406 nm) source. XRD patterns were collected in the 2-theta range of 5–50° at a rate of 6°/min. Raman spectra were measured on an inVia Raman Microscope (Renishaw, U.K.). 532 nm was chosen as exciting wavelength, and the Raman spectra were collected from 100 to 1000 cm−1. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analyses giving the surface morphology of the samples were conducted on a FEI Inspect F50 (FSEM) microscope operating at 15 kV. Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments of the samples in H2 were conducted from 100 to 700 °C on a multi-function dynamic adsorption instrument (DAS-7000) using a quartz tube loaded with 50 mg of catalyst. After pretreating the catalyst in situ under N2 flow at 400 °C for 40 min and cooling to the desired temperature, the reduction reaction was measured in a mixture atmosphere of 5% H2/Ar using a heating rate of 8 °C/min at a flow rate of 30 mL/min. The H2 consumption was continuously monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) tests were carried out at room temperature using a Bruker EMX plus instrument to probe the coordination environment of paramagnetic isolated Cu2+ ions. 27Al NMR MAS spectroscopy was carried out on the Agilent DSX-300 spectrometer using a standard Agilent magic Angle rotation (MAS) probe with a 4 mm (outside diameter) zirconia rotor. The temperature programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) experiments were achieved on a self-built equipment. Prior to the adsorption of NH3, 200 mg of catalyst was pretreated under N2 of 30 mL/min at 400 °C for 1 h. When the temperature cooled down to desired temperature, the sample was fed to 4.0% NH3/He gas mixture of 30 mL/min for 40 min. Subsequently, N2 purging was carried out for 20 min and NH3 desorption was performed from 100 to 600 °C. Meanwhile, the desorbed NH3 was continuously detected by a quadrupole mass spectrometer (Hiden Analytical HA-085-172). In situ DRIFTS experiments were carried out through a Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FTIR, Nicolet iS50) with a MCT/A detector. Prior to each experiment, the catalyst in IR chamber was purged at 400 °C for 30 min in mixture flow of N2+Air to remove impurities. Then the system was cooled as a function of temperature and the background spectra were collected in N2 atmosphere simultaneously. Next, a controlled stream of 600 ppm NH3/N2 at a flow rate of 100 mL/min was fed into the sample cell at 100 °C for 40 min, and then the sample was purged by N2 with increasing the temperature from 100 to 400 °C. All spectra of catalysts were collected after reaching the desired conditions. 2.3 Catalytic activity tests The NH3-SCR activity measurements of samples were carried out using 0.4 mL catalyst on a sieve fraction of 40–60 mesh, placed in a fixed-bed quartz reactor (i.d. 6 mm). The total flow rate of the reactant gas mixture (600 ppm NH3, 600 ppm NO, 5% O2 and N2 as balance) was 400 mL/min with a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 60,000 h−1. The inlet and outlet analyses of NH3 and NO x (NO and NO2) concentration were determined by ammonia analyzer (GXH-1050E) and flue gas analyzer (ECOM•J2KN), respectively. The by-product of N2O was detected by a gas chromatograph (GC-9790) equipped with an electron capture detector (ECD). The conversion of NO x was calculated by the following formula. (1) N O x c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = ( [ N O x ] i n − [ N O x ] o u t [ N O x ] i n ) × 100 2.4 Kinetic measurements The standard NH3-SCR reaction rates were conducted in a quartz tube (i.d. 4 mm) at atmospheric pressure using 20 mg catalyst of 40–60 mesh. The GHSV of 1.2 × 106 and total flow rate of 400 mL/min were used to eliminate the internal and external diffusion. The steady-state NOx below 20% was completed at a temperature interval of 20 °C. In this paper, the NH3-SCR reaction rate per unit mass (RNOx) was calculated via the following formula: (2) R NOx = X NOx · Y NOx · V 22.4 W where the RNOx was the SCR rate, XNOx was the conversion of NO, YNOx was NO concentration in inlet, V was the total flow rate of the flow gas, and W was the mass of catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Comparison of NH3-SCR catalytic performance for catalysts The catalytic performances of the fresh and aged Cu/SAPO-34 or Cu/La-SAPO-34 catalysts for SCR were shown in Fig. 1 . It was evident from Fig. 1(a) and (b) that the Cu/S-fresh and Cu/La-S-fresh presented the similar activity and both of them showed the prominent low-temperature SCR activity with approximately 100% of NO x conversion at 175–375 °C. It could be seen that the NO x conversion of fresh catalysts declined mildly when the reaction temperature rose from 375 °C to 450 °C. In addition, in order to reveal the hydrothermal aging performance of copper-based zeolite catalysts and the effect of La doping on hydrothermal stability of these catalysts, we treated fresh samples in 10 vol% H2O/air at different temperatures for 10 h to obtain the samples after hydrothermal aging. Interestingly, the catalytic activity of copper-based zeolite catalysts was much dependent on the hydrothermal temperature and La doping. Lower hydrothermal temperature of 650 °C had little impact on both catalysts. As the hydrothermal temperature rose from 650 °C to 750 °C, the activity of Cu/S-750 decreased dramatically and reached a maximum NO x conversion of approximately 60% at 400 °C. It was gratifying that the activity of La doping samples (Cu/La-S-750) had been maintained at an excellent level, which suggested that La doping did play a great role in stabilizing the high temperature hydrothermal aging performance of the catalyst. However, both catalysts failed to survive at higher hydrothermal temperature, which might be due to the fact that the SAPO-34 structure and isolated Cu2+ ions were severely damaged at a temperature of 850 °C. For a better evaluation of catalytic performance of catalysts, investigation of the production of N2O as a by-product was crucial. The measurement results of N2O concentration were shown in Fig. 1(c) and (d). The N2O concentrations of both fresh samples were below 5 ppm. Although the N2O concentration enhanced with the increase of the hydrothermal aging temperature, the N2O concentration of all catalysts was lower than 50 ppm, especially the N2O concentration of La doped samples was always lower than 15 ppm. This phenomenon demonstrated that the doping of La could not only improve the high-temperature hydrothermal stability of the catalysts, but also enhance the N2 selectivity. Moreover, when the Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/La-SAPO-34 catalysts were subjected to hydrothermal aging treatment at 750 °C for 32 h (Fig. S1), the activities of Cu/S-750-32 h and Cu/La-S-750-32 h were very close to those of the samples treated for 10 h. It indicated that the time of hydrothermal aging treatment had little effect on the hydrothermal stability of the catalysts. It had been reported that hydrothermal treatment at low temperature (70 °C) caused serious decline in efficiency of Cu/SAPO-34 [30]. For comparison, the catalytic activities of Cu/S-LTH and Cu/La-S-LTH treating with low temperature hydrothermal aging (LTH, 70 °C for 16 h) were also conducted and the results were presented in Fig. S2. The activities of both Cu/S-LTH and Cu/La-S-LTH decreased compared with the corresponding fresh samples. However, it was obvious that the activity of Cu/La-S-LTH declined the most, proving that La doping also promoted the low temperature hydrothermal stability of the Cu/SAPO-34. 3.2 N2 adsorption-desorption experiments The impact of hydrothermal temperature on the textural properties of all catalysts were clearly shown in Fig. 2 and Table 1 . It could be discovered that the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of all catalysts were classified into type IV based on the IUPAC standard (Fig. 2(a) and (b)), signifying the presence of mesopores [29]. Beside, the pore size distribution curves in Fig. 2(c) and (d) also supported the existence of mesopores (2–50 nm). However, when the hydrothermal temperature increased to 850 °C, no apparent hysteresis loop could be observed on Cu/S-850 and Cu/La-S-850, indicating that the pore structure of the catalysts was seriously destroyed under too high aging temperature. As expected, the Cu/S-fresh and Cu/La-S-fresh catalysts exhibited the large BET surface area of 158.1 and 140.9 m2/g and pores of about 11.2 and 12.0 nm in diameter, respectively. The BET surface area of both Cu/S and Cu/La-S decreased linearly with rising the hydrothermal temperature. Fortunately, the introduction of La significantly inhibited the collapse of pore structure of catalysts under hydrothermal treatment of 750 °C. 3.3 XRD analysis Fig. 3 gave the XRD characterization of fresh and aged Cu/SAPO-34 or Cu/La-SAPO-34 catalysts to unravel the effect of hydrothermal aging on the zeolite structure and copper species. As could be seen from XRD patterns, both fresh catalysts exhibited the typical diffraction peaks of SAPO-34 ascribed to the CHA phase (PDF no. 47-0168) [31]. While no diffraction peaks attributed to Cu or CuO x phase could be found [32], which was probably owing to the high dispersion of copper species or the presence of isolate Cu2+. Moreover, only the intensities of diffraction peaks of Cu/S-650 and Cu/La-S-650 weakened compared with that of fresh samples, meaning that lower hydrothermal aging temperature only reduced the crystallinity of the zeolite, which did not deactivate the catalysts. When the hydrothermal aging temperature increases to 750 °C and 850 °C, the diffraction peaks of both catalysts changed significantly. These changes were mainly reflected in two aspects: (1) The original diffraction peaks of SAPO-34 changed and almost completely disappeared; (2) new diffraction peaks appeared at other 2θ locations (PDF no. 50-1431 for SiO2 and PDF no. 50-0302 for AlPO4). These phenomena indicated that the CHA structure collapsed irregularly at a higher hydrothermal temperature. The SiO2 and AlPO4 species observed in XRD could be further speculated that the CHA framework structure was destroyed [20]. In addition, the peaks at 2θ = 35.5° and 38.7° corresponding to the CuO species (PDF no. 45-0937) illustrated that the originally isolated Cu2+ partially transformed into CuO in the process of hydrothermal aging [32]. In particular, some weak peaks belonging to the LaPO4 species (PDF no. 32-0493) appeared on the Cu/La-S-850, indicating that La3+ combined with the PO4 3−-like ions detached from the framework to form the LaPO4 species under the harsh conditions of hydrothermal treatment [33]. Nonetheless, there were obvious differences between the two kinds of catalysts. For example, compared with Cu/S-750 and Cu/S-850, although some new diffraction peaks of SiO2 appeared in Cu/La-S-750 and Cu/La-S-850, the CHA structure was still retained at 750 °C. And the diffraction peaks were much weaker than that of Cu/S-750 and Cu/S-850. In addition, the diffraction peaks intensities of CuO species on Cu/La-S-750 and Cu/La-S-850 were much feebler than that on La-free samples. Furthermore, we calculated the grain size of CuO according to the well-known Scherrer formula [34,35] and giving a decreasing order of Cu/S-850 (30 nm) > Cu/S-750 (27 nm) > Cu/La-S-850 (24 nm) > Cu/La-S-750 (19 nm). These results indicated that the addition of La could vastly slow down the collapse of the CHA structure and restrain the transformation of isolated Cu2+ to CuO cluster. Therefore, Cu/ La-S-750 samples still maintained excellent SCR activity at 750 °C. 3.4 Raman analysis For the purpose of further investigation on copper species and zeolite structure, the Raman spectra of fresh and aged Cu/SAPO-34 or Cu/La-SAPO-34 catalysts were depicted in Fig. 4 . It was interesting to find that no Raman active modes presented on two fresh samples [36]. Similarly, there was no describable Raman band detected on the Cu/S-650 and Cu/La-S-650 when the hydrothermal aging temperature was only 650 °C. It could be concluded that CuO species was highly dispersed on the support because of the absence of peaks attributing to CuO species, which was in the good accord with the XRD results [37]. With the temperature rising up to 750 °C and 850 °C, three Raman bands around 277–281, 320–326 and 611–619 cm−1, respectively belonging to Ag and 2Bg modes in CuO nanoparticles were observed [37,38]. The peaks strengths augmented with the increase of the hydrothermal aging temperature, and the strengths of these three peaks over aged Cu/SAPO-34 catalysts were much higher than that of aged Cu/La-SAPO-34 catalysts, demonstrating that the copper oxide species on Cu/SAPO-34 were easier to aggregate. The amelioration in the dispersion of copper species under hydrothermal conditions could be clarified by this fact that the addition of La effectively inhibited the transformation of Cu2+ ions to CuO and the aggregation of CuO. Moreover, with the rise of hydrothermal aging temperature, the peaks of SiO2 (289–293 and 452–466 cm−1) were observed at Cu/S-750, Cu/S-850, Cu/La-S-750 and Cu/La-S-850 catalysts, which were also consistent with XRD results [32,39]. Differently, a new peak belonging to LaPO4 species only formed on Cu/La-S-750 and Cu/La-S-850 [40]. 3.5 SEM measurements As confirmed by SEM investigation in Figs. 5 and 6 , the morphologies of fresh samples Cu/S-fresh and Cu/La-S-fresh were analogous with each other, exhibiting varied size of spherical aggregates with smooth surface (Figs. 5a and 6a). This phenomenon elucidated that the introduction of La made a mild effect on the morphology and structure of catalysts, which was in line with the XRD results. After hydrothermal aging at different temperatures, the spherical aggregates were broken into small fragments, showing irregular and clumpy morphologies with different aggregation degrees (Fig. 5a-1, d-1and Fig. 6a-1, d-1). These lumpy aggregates became looser and rougher with the hydrothermal temperature ascending. It was worth mentioning here that the rough of catalysts surface was not only due to the small debris caused by the structural failure of CHA, but also might be resulted from the new CuO particles produced on the support surface. It could be clearly observed from the high resolution SEM images of Figs. 5d-2 and 6d-2 that when the hydrothermal temperature rose up to 850 °C, a large number of CuO particles presented on the surface of the block over Cu/S-850 and Cu/La-S-850 (red circle in Figs. 5 and 6), which was consistent with the phenomena observed by XRD and Raman. 3.6 Catalysts reducibility (H2-TPR) With the purpose of obtaining the existence state of copper species loaded on the SAPO-34 and La-exchanged SAPO-34, in Fig. 7 H2-TPR profiles of these fresh and aged catalysts were displayed, showing the influence of the hydrothermal aging treatment on the Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/La-SAPO-34 reduction behavior under hydrogen flow. According to our previous study and other literature [29,41], the H2 consumption peaks located below 400 °C were usually assigned to the reduction from isolated Cu2+ to Cu+. And the reduction peaks ascribed to the further reduction from Cu+ to Cu° could be observed at above 400 °C. It was worth noting that the CuO reduction to Cu0 was always done in one step, therefore offering one reduction peak below 400 °C [29,41]. There were several general reduction peaks for both fresh catalysts as reported in Fig. 7, corresponding to the reduction of isolated Cu2+ (Cu(OH)+-Z, 8MR) to Cu+ in the eight-membered rings (200–250 °C), CuO to Cu0 (250–300 °C), isolated Cu2+ (Cu2+−2Z, 6MR) to Cu+ in the six-membered rings (300–360 °C), and Cu+ to Cu0 (> 400 °C), respectively [13]. The differences were that the reduction peak belonging to the CuO reduction to Cu0 appeared on Cu/La-S-fresh rather than Cu/S-fresh. Admittedly, CuO species had the excellent redox ability, under the SCR reaction atmosphere, NO could be rapidly oxidized to NO2, leading to “fast SCR” reaction [42]. Therefore, the presence of an appropriate amount of copper oxide might be contributed to the low temperature SCR activity of the catalyst. It could be seen from Fig. 7 that Cu/S-650 and Cu/La-S-650 exhibited the similar H2-TPR profiles after hydrothermal aging at 650 °C, and thus resulting in the similar catalytic activity. Differently, the peaks assigning to the reduction of isolated Cu2+ on Cu/S-650 became more distinct than Cu/S-fresh due to the transformation from irreducible copper species to reducible Cu2+ species under low-temperature hydrothermal aging. As for the Cu/La-S-650, the peaks assigning to the reduction of isolated Cu2+ also strengthened, whereas the feature belonging to the CuO absent, which might be due to the transformation from CuO to Cu2+ ions at low-temperature hydrothermal aging. It was well accepted that isolated Cu2+ ions as active SCR sites was related to the remarkable SCR activity [22,23]. For Cu/SAPO-34 catalyst, however, the reduction profiles showed great changes when the hydrothermal temperature further increased to 750 °C and 850 °C. In general, a flat peak (299 °C) and a sharp peak (287 °C) belonging to the CuO species could be observed on Cu/S-750 and Cu/S-850, separately. Moreover, the H2 consumption peak (350–400 °C) ascribed to CuAlO2 species originating from the interaction between Cu2+ and Al(OH)3 species resulted from framework dealumination was also generated in Cu/S-750 and Cu/S-850 [43]. Based on the above changes of copper species embodied in H2-TPR results, it was reasonable to believe that the decreased isolated Cu2+ transformed to CuO species or CuAlO2 species during the hydrothermal aging at 750 °C and 850 °C. Abundant CuO species facilitated the occurrence of non-selective NH3 oxidation at high temperature (>350 °C), and induced the decrease of reductant NH3 as well as formation of NO x (NO and NO2) [21,44]. In this process, the formation of NO2 was not conducive to low-temperature SCR reaction. On the contrary, the denitration efficiency at high temperature was reduced due to the consumption of NH3. Notably, the copper species on La-doped sample did not change significantly with the increase of hydrothermal temperature to 750 °C, and obvious peak belonging to isolated Cu2+ could still be observed, concluding that exchanged La ions could preferably stable copper species as well as the CHA structure, as stated in Figs. 3 and 4. This indicated that the excellent resistance to hydrothermal aging over Cu/La-S-750 was due to the doping of La. In addition, although the copper species and CHA structure of the La-added catalyst was unavoidably damaged when the hydrothermal aging temperature was too high, the degree of damage was not as great as that of the La-free catalyst, which was why the activity of Cu/La-S-850 was slightly better than that of Cu/S-850. 3.7 EPR analysis In order to further identify and quantify the isolated Cu2+ species in the fresh and aged catalysts, EPR experiment was performed at room temperature, which was only responsive to isolated Cu2+ ions but not active to other Cu species (CuO, Cu+, etc.) [13]. As displayed in Fig. 8 , g// = 2.39 and A// = 121 G signal was recorded with the Cu/S-fresh and Cu/La-S-fresh, belong to the isolated Cu2+ in 6MR [7,20]. The intensity of EPR spectrum for Cu/S-fresh was slightly stronger than that of Cu/La-S-fresh, suggesting that the less isolated Cu2+ ions presented on Cu/La-S-fresh owing to the existence of CuO species observed in H2-TPR profile (Fig. 7(b)). Interestingly, the amount of isolated Cu2+ in Cu/S-650 and Cu/La-S-650 increased after hydrothermal treatment at 650 °C, which was supported by the increased signals, contributing to the improved catalytic activity as shown in Fig. 1. When the hydrothermal temperature rose to 750 °C, g// = 2.32 and A// = 154 G signal was clearly recorded with Cu/S-750 sample, corresponding to Cu2+ ions coordinated with SiO2 due to the destruction of zeolite framework [20,45], which further verified the formation of SiO2 detected in XRD and Raman characteristics. Fortunately, the framework structure and active isolated Cu2+ ions of Cu/La-S-750 was well retained, indicating that the addition of La could inhibit the structure collapse, so that the catalyst retained a high catalytic activity. In addition, it could be seen that no apparent EPR signal appeared on Cu/S-850 and Cu/La-S-850 due to the serious loss of isolated Cu2+ ions, which was well consistent with the H2-TPR results. 3.8 27Al MAS NMR analysis In order to understand the changes in the coordination environment of framework Al and extra-framework Al during hydrothermal aging, 27Al MAS NMR experiments were employed and the results were displayed in Fig. 9 . Two distinct peaks and a shoulder peak could be observed on both fresh Cu/S-fresh and Cu/La-S-fresh samples. The two main peaks located at 37 and −13 ppm were attributed to tetrahedrally coordinated framework aluminum species (Altetra) and octahedrally coordinated aluminum atoms (Aloct) generated from Altetra coordinated witn two H2O molecules, respectively. Whereas, the shoulder peak at 15 ppm was belonging to pentacoordinated aluminum species (Alpen) [46]. After hydrothermal aging at 750 °C, only a contractive peak at 38 ppm was found on Cu/S-750, with the loss of peak at −13 ppm belonging to a damage of Brønsted acid sites caused by bridging OH groups (Si–O(H)–Al). Differently, the Cu/La-S-750 showed similar characteristics to that of Cu/La-S-fresh, and the signal at −13 ppm in Cu/La-S-750 was more stronger than that in Cu/S-750, which mirrored the zeolite featured H2O absorption ability with enough acidity [42]. These phenomena demonstrated that doping of La suppressed dealumination and reduced the loss of acid sites under high temperature hydrothermal aging. In other word, Cu/La-S-750 presented better hydrothermal stability than Cu/S-750, which was in line with the results of XRD and Raman. 3.9 Surface acidity of catalysts 3.9.1 NH3-TPD Fig. 10 (a) and (b) showed the NH3-TPD profiles of catalysts, which giving the imperative findings of the surface acidity of all the samples. The corresponding values for the area of NH3 desorption peaks were given in Fig. 10(c) and (d). The acid sites on the catalyst surface could be divided into three types depending on the different ammonia desorption temperature: weak acid sites (100–200 °C), medium-strong acid sites (200–350 °C) and strong acid sites (> 350 °C) [38,47]. The NH3-TPD profiles of Cu/S-fresh and Cu/S-La-fresh featured three desorption peaks at various temperatures (denoted as α, β and γ, respectively), indicating the existence of the above three types of acid sites. In addition, a large amount of desorbed NH3 was observed for Cu/La-S-fresh (total amount of 0.904 mmol/g) and mainly Cu/S-fresh catalyst (total amount of 0.982 mmol/g). Although the total amount of NH3 on Cu/La-S-fresh was lower than that of Cu/S-fresh, the amount of desorbed NH3 in the middle temperature segment was same (Fig. 10). The desorption peaks of Cu/La-S-fresh shifted slightly to higher temperature compared with that of Cu/S-fresh, demonstrating that the acid strength of Cu/La-S-fresh was stronger than Cu/S-fresh. It could be found from the Fig. 10(c) and (d) that the amount of surface acid sites of samples reduced with the increase of hydrothermal temperature. Especially when the hydrothermal temperature rose up to 750 °C, the amount of acid sites on the surface of two catalysts was significantly different. Cu/S-750 catalyst scarcely possessed acid sites, exhibiting only small amounts of desorbed NH3 in the whole temperature regions. Instead, Cu/La-S-750 showed a relatively large amount of acid sites in a wide temperature window. Hence, it was suggested that the addition of La was more favorable for acid sites protection. Unfortunately, the NH3 desorption curves of the Cu/S-850 and Cu/La-S-850 catalyst were almost linear, indicating that the surface acidity of both catalysts declined dramatically with or without La doping. With the combination of activity and characterization results, including XRD, Raman, and TPD, it could be reasonably speculated that the role of La was not to increase the surface acidity of the catalysts but to protect the zeolite framework from destruction. Even under the more severe hydrothermal aging conditions, the CHA structure damage will be minimized. Therefore, the retention and disappearance of catalyst acidity depended on the degree of structural damage. Furthermore, an appropriate amount of acid sites was more conducive to the catalytic activity of the catalysts. 3.9.2 In situ drifts analysis of NH3 adsorption-desorption In order to further understand the surface acid properties of catalysts including acid types and acid strength as well as intermediates produced during the evolution of adsorbed ammonia, in situ DRIFTS measurements of NH3 adsorption-desorption over the fresh and aged samples were carried out at different temperature and the results were presented in Figs. 11 and 12 . Figs. 11(a) and 12(a) gave the surface acidity of fresh and aged Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/La-SAPO-34 catalysts, respectively. A series of temperature-dependent DRIFT spectra recorded during NH3 exposure and subsequent purge in N2 flow of fresh and aged Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/La-SAPO-34 catalysts were also displayed in Figs. 11(b) (and Fig. S3) and 12(b) (and Fig. S3). With regard to the fresh Cu/S-fresh catalyst (Fig. 11(a)), several strong bands developing around 3341, 3257, 3167, 1687, 1611, 1454 and 1249–1274 cm−1 were found. As reported in literature [48–50], the bands at 3341, 3257 and 3167 cm−1 were usually ascribed to the N–H stretching vibration modes of the NH3 coordinated on Lewis (L) acid sites. The bands at 1687 and 1454 cm−1 could be assigned to the symmetric and asymmetric bending vibrations of NH4 + bound to Brønsted (B) acid sites. The bands at 1611 and 1249–1274 cm−1 were attributed to the asymmetric and symmetric bending vibrations of coordinated NH3 on Lewis acid sites. It was worth noting that two negative bands located at 3666 and 3600 cm−1 were also found on Cu/S-fresh catalyst, which belonged to the depletion of P-OH sites and Si-OH-Al bonds causing by the adsorbed NH3, respectively [51,52]. Cu/S-fresh showed great advantages in acid sites than that of Cu/La-S-fresh (Fig. 12(a)). Beside, along with increasing temperature, the surface adsorbed NH3 species (L and B acid sites) changed mildly. However, it could be visually observed from Figs. 11(b) and S3(a) that the reduction degree of L acid sites was lower than that of B acid sites. At the same time, in the entire adsorption-desorption process, except for the L and B acid sites, no intermediates resulted from the evolution of ammonia appeared, indicating that the adsorbed ammonia species were relatively stable during the entire temperature rise process, which was conducive to the participation in NO x reduction reaction. Particularly, the adsorbed ammonia species on L acid sites were more stable than that on B acid sites. The surface acidity of fresh Cu/La-S-fresh catalyst was close to the fresh Cu/S-fresh sample (Fig. 12(a)). It could be clearly observed that several bands corresponding to OH species, L acid sites and B acid sites appeared at 3660/3618 cm−1, 3400–3100/1606/1261–1304 cm−1 and 1684/1441 cm−1, respectively. Differently, Fig. 12 illustrated that surface acid sites of Cu/La-S-fresh was less than that of Cu/S-fresh sample, demonstrating that doping of La gave an unfavorable effect on surface acidity of catalyst, which was quite similar to the NH3-TPD results (Fig. 10). Moreover, it could be found from Figs. 12(b) and S3(b) that the bands assigned to B acid sites (1684 and 1441 cm−1) decreased slowly and the weak band at 1441 cm−1 vanished at 300 °C. On the contrary, the weak band (1606 cm−1) and strong band (1261–1304 cm−1) attributed to the L acid sites had hardly changed. When the N2 purge temperature reached 400 °C, the bands intensities were similar to the initial temperature of 100 °C. Although the acid sites of Cu/La-S-fresh were notable less than that of Cu/S-fresh, the acid strength of Cu/La-S-fresh was slightly stronger than that of Cu/S-fresh, which could also be confirmed by the desorption peak of Cu/La-S-fresh shifted to high-temperature in NH3-TPD. Interestingly, the variation trend of acid sites over different catalysts was similar to that detected by NH3-TPD. After hydrothermal aging treatment at 650 °C (Figs. 11(a) and 12(a)), the bands mentioned above were well retained in the DRIFT spectra of the Cu/S-650 and Cu/La-S-650 catalysts, with the difference that the peak intensities changed. In other words, the surface acidity of the two samples did not change substantially, but the amount of surface acid sites decreased obviously after aging treatment. Moreover, the new bands at 3593 and 1210 cm−1 were observed on Cu/La-S-650 catalysts (Fig. 12(a)), which were separately assigned to the consumption of Si-OH-Al bonds and L acid sites [48,51]. Nevertheless, the total acid amounts on Cu/S-650 sample were still higher than that on Cu/La-S-650 sample, which could also be identified by the NH3-TPD profiles. As the hydrothermal temperature further increased to 750 °C, interestingly, only a few very weak signals belonging to acid sites were observed on Cu/S-750 catalyst (Fig. 11(a)). However, several striking signals mentioned above could still be observed on Cu/La-S-750 sample (Fig. 12(a)), resulting from the protective effect of La ion on the zeolite structure. Unfortunately, when the hydrothermal temperature rose up to 850 °C, doping of La no longer played a significant role in protecting the zeolite structure due to the harsh hydrothermal conditions. Herein, the acid sites on both Cu/S-850 and Cu/La-S-850 samples were almost destroyed. Clearly, Figs. 11 and 12 gave the information that almost all the signals corresponding to the acid sites disappeared. 3.10 NH3-SCR kinetic studies In order to further elucidate the inherent properties of NH3-SCR on all catalysts, NH3-SCR kinetic measurements were carried out after excluding the heat and mass transfer effects. The apparent activation energy (Ea) for each sample could be evaluated through the Arrhenius plots (Fig. 13 ) to measure the catalytic activity, where low Ea value of materials signaled the excellent activity [13]. Based on Fig. 13(a), the Ea values of fresh and aged Cu/SAPO-34 samples followed the ascending order: Cu/S-650 (20.76 kJ mol−1) < Cu/S-fresh (21.75 kJ mol−1) < Cu/S-750 (38.61 kJ mol−1) < Cu/S-850 (41,69 kJ mol−1). This trend was completely consistent with the decreased catalytic activity of Cu/SAPO-34 catalyst. In other words, the Ea values were inversely proportional to the catalytic activity, proving that the Cu/S-650 catalyst indeed had the outstanding catalytic activity. As for the La modified samples shown in Fig. 13(b), Cu/La-S-650 possessed the lowest Ea value (20.35 kJ mol−1) while the best catalytic activity, suggesting that the catalytic performance of Cu/La-S-650 was ameliorated via hydrothermal aging treatment. Similarly, the Ea value of La-doped sample increased with further enhancing the hydrothermal temperature to 750 and 850 °C, corresponding to the decreased catalytic activity. Generally, these results were in line with the performance of the catalyst from the kinetic experiment results. 4 Discussion It was well known that the destruction of zeolite structure and transformation of copper species in the process of high temperature hydrothermal aging were the two nonnegligible factors leading to the inactivation of copper-based zeolite catalysts [13,14,19,20]. In our previous work [29], we had found that the catalytic activity of Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst was susceptible to hydrothermal aging, but the introduction of Ce or La ions effectively inhibited this phenomenon. It could be clearly observed that the doping of rare earth metal ions could effectively retard the collapse of CHA skeleton structure (dealumination) through XRD and 27Al MAS NMR characterization. Moreover, it was also observed that the isolated Cu2+ ions were well maintained under the condition of hydrothermal aging at 700 °C through the characterization of TPR and UV–vis DRS results. Differently and innovatively, in this study, elaborate exploration on the relationships among copper species, zeolite structure, catalyst surface acidity and SCR performance at variant hydrothermal aging temperatures (650, 750 and 850 °C) was carried out. As a general consensus, Cu2+ ion species were billed as active SCR sites, which were prone to migrate in the process of high temperature hydrothermal aging and thus became CuO x particles or even aggregated into CuO x clusters [21,22,53]. It could be seen from XRD, Raman, SEM, H2-TPR and EPR results described above that Cu2+ ion species on both catalysts of Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/La-SAPO-34 were well maintained when the hydrothermal temperature was relatively low such as 650 °C. With the further increase of the hydrothermal temperature to 750 °C, the copper species on Cu/SAPO-34 underwent a significant transformation, and the signals belonging to the Cu2+ ions were significantly weakened or even disappeared (seen in Fig. 7 of H2-TPR), whereas the new signals attributed to the CuO species appeared (seen in Fig. 3 of XRD, Fig. 4 of Raman and Fig. 7 of H2-TPR). Adversely, this phenomenon was not found on Cu/La-SAPO-34 sample, indicating that addition of La could stabilize the active Cu2+ sites. Although the copper species on both catalysts changed significantly under very harsh hydrothermal conditions, the results of Cu/La-S-850 were slightly better than those of Cu/S-850. Interestingly, these variations were very consistent with the SCR performances of the catalysts, inferring that CuO detrimentally impacted the SCR catalytic activity of catalysts. For example, on the one hand, the formed CuO species would give rise to the loss of active SCR sites [23,54], which might also be related to the loss of surface acid sites (discussed later). On the other hand, CuO accelerated the occurrence of non-selective NH3 oxidation [21,44,55], which might also be associated with the weakened surface acidity (discussed later). Both of these inferences could be verified in Fig. S4. As shown in Fig. S4 of NH3 oxidation results, both kinds of fresh catalysts could achieve complete NH3 conversion at 400 °C with low NOx (NO and NO2) and N2O yields. Moreover, these phenomena were well maintained in Cu/S-650, Cu/La-S-650 and Cu/La-S-750, demonstrating the poor ability of ammonia oxidation over these catalysts and excellent NH3-SCR activity. Unfortunately, the complete NH3 conversion achieved on Cu/S-750, Cu/S-850 at 375 °C catalysts and the yields of NOx (NO and NO2) and N2O were enhanced substantially. More importantly, the formed CuO cluster originated from the transformation of Cu2+ could induce the structural failure, which was considered as the key factor for zeolite catalyst deactivation during hydrothermal aging [13]. As illustrated in Figs. 3 and 4 (XRD and Raman), it could be distinctly observed that La-free Cu/SAPO-34 catalyst suffered severe structure damage when the hydrothermal temperature rose up to 750 and 850 °C, whereas the zeolite structure of La-doping catalyst was well maintained at 750 °C. Furthermore, the destruction of zeolite structure eventually led to the loss of acid sites on the catalyst surface, which was evidenced by combining XRD (Raman) with NH3-TPD (DRIFTS) results (Figs. 10–12). It was general accepted that abundant surface acid sites and moderate acid strength availed the adsorption and activation of NH3, which was conductive to the outstanding NH3-SCR performance [15,29,56,57]. The adsorption capacity of ammonia on the Cu/S-750, Cu/S-850 and Cu/La-S-850 catalysts reduced due to the decrease of surface acid sites. However, the adsorbed ammonia species were more likely to be oxidized by active oxygen species and underwent non-selective ammonia oxidation reaction because of the weakening of acid strength (Figs. 11 and 12). These phenomena were bound to induce the inferior SCR activity and N2 selectively [44]. In other words, the addition of La into CHA structure vastly restrained the transformation of Cu2+ ions to CuO x species, alleviated the damage of CHA structure and loss of surface acid sites, which were in favor of the SCR performance after hydrothermal treatment at 750 °C jointly. 5 Conclusions To summarize, Cu/SAPO-34 and La functionalized Cu/SAPO-34 were successfully fabricated by the way of ion exchange method as well as wet impregnation approach, in which its structure and surface acidity could be fine-tailored via doping of La. NH3-SCR tests showed that the catalytic activity of La-free Cu/SAPO-34 sample greatly depended on the hydrothermal aging temperature compared with that of Cu/La-SAPO-34. Catalytic activity in combination with characterization results could evidence that both zeolite structure and copper species supporting on SAPO-34 zeolite appeared to be influenced by hydrothermal conditions to different degrees, which directly affected the catalytic activity of both catalysts. Cu/SAPO-34 catalyst lost most of its deNO x activity after hydrothermal aging at 750 °C, while the outstanding activity of Cu/La-SAPO-34 catalyst hardly changed. The XRD, Raman, SEM and H2-TPR results exhibited that SAPO-34 structure of La-free sample was deeply damaged and most of the isolated Cu2+ ions were converted to bulk CuO species when hydrothermal temperature rose up to 750 °C and 850 °C. Interestingly, all of these over Cu/La-SAPO-34 were slightly influenced than that on Cu/SAPO-34. Additionally, NH3-TPD and in situ DRIFTS analyses revealed that the addition of La was more favorable for acid sites protection and the surface acid sites on both catalysts also impacted by the hydrothermal treatment. Notably, all of the copper species, zeolite structure and surface acidity were closely related to the NH3-SCR performance of the Cu-based zeolite catalyst. coredata.dc:description: During the high-temperature hydrothermal aging process, the tolerance of the zeolite structure and the stability of the active Cu2+ ions directly determined the denitration (deNO x ) performance of the copper-based zeolite catalysts in automobile exhaust treatment. Herein, we displayed the hydrothermal aging stability of La-free and La-doped Cu/SAPO-34 catalysts at variant temperatures (650, 750 and 850 °C). A series of characterization results signified that the addition of La into SAPO-34 framework by ion exchange method had obvious contribution to hold back the collapse of SAPO-34 structure and transformation of isolated Cu2+ ions. Different from Cu/SAPO-34 catalyst, Cu/La-SAPO-34 catalyst was more prone to maintain its superior catalytic activity after hydrothermal aging at 750 °C, which possessed great application potential. In addition, NH3-TPD and DRIFT spectra shed light on the variation of surface acidity over two kinds of catalysts inducing by hydrothermal treatment. It could be discovered that doping of La provided moderate surface acidity and excellent hydrothermal stability for Cu/SAPO-34 even up to 750 °C, which was in favor of the NH3-SCR reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Insights into the impact of lanthanum on hydrothermal-induced migration and transformation of copper species in Cu/SAPO-34 catalyst for NH3-SCR
